intro: Gompholobium burtonioides, commonly known as the Burton's wattle, is a shrub native to Western Australia. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod fruits. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its flowers are usually yellow or orange, appearing in clusters along the stems. It plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and habitat for small fauna.
